title: Question 53

children: A 25-year-old woman presents with vaginal discharge and itching and dysuria.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Trichomoniasis is the diagnosis, as motile trichomonads (

on this vaginal wet mount. Trichomonads are slightly larger than leukocytes, are usually oval or pear shaped, and have flagella. Women with trichomoniasis may be asymptomatic or present with copious vaginal discharge that is malodorous, pale yellow or gray, frothy, and associated with vulvar itching and burning. Microscopy with examination of a wet mount can establish the diagnosis when positive, but false-negative test results are common. Nucleic acid amplification testing or rapid antigen testing may be used as the primary diagnostic test or if the suspicion of trichomoniasis is high but the wet mount result is negative.
